findings.title: TM27. Two-Person Rule/No-Lone Zone is not implemented
findings.description: The two-person rule/no-lone zone is not implemented on production servers, which could lead to potential weaknesses in access control and authentication.

findings.title: TM28. Missing Key Rotation policy for MySQL/MongoDB
findings.description: The implementation team noted that while they did support key rotation, this was not currently implemented within the system.

findings.title: TM29. Infrastructure hosted outside the US
findings.description: There are no procedural protections to prevent Voatz infrastructure from being hosted outside of the United States.

findings.title: TM30. Lacking a pool of pre-generated keys or multiple certs pinned
findings.description: The implementation team noted that all servers use the same, wild-card TLS certificate for all public facing applications. An attacker with access to any server with key material could create their own instance of Voatz infrastructure with known-good certificates.

findings.title: TM31. Use of a custom crypto layer below TLS without pinning
findings.description: The implementation uses a custom crypto layer below TLS without key pinning, allowing an attacker with sufficient position to present a new key to the mobile application and man-in-the-middle any connections going forward.

findings.title: Missing Security Category (SC) as per FIPS-199/200
findings.description: The Voatz team did not select a Security Category (SC) as noted in NIST 800-53, page IV, which is required to determine the baseline set of controls from NIST 800-53.

findings.title: Missing Data Classification
findings.description: The implementation lacks a data classification system, which is required by ISO27001 and NIST 800-53 control frameworks, making it difficult for developers to know how to handle information processed by individual components within the system.

findings.title: Policies do not follow NIST 800-61/800-34
findings.description: The Voatz system does not have a disaster recovery process based on NIST 800-61 and 800-34, which may hinder normal operation resumption in the event of an attack or disaster.

findings.title: Missing and Incomplete Documentation
findings.description: The implementation team noted that documentation was missing or incomplete throughout the system.

findings.title: Incident Response is not automated and is under-documented
findings.description: The implementation team noted that Incident Response and Threat Hunting processes were neither automated nor directly documented.

findings.title: Risk management is lacking
findings.description: The implementation team noted that their risk management setup did not include robust threat intelligence, threat hunting, automated actor extraction, and lacked defined processes for accepting, triaging, contextualizing risk, or even identifying risk within the organization.

findings.title: Voter identity verification is manual with minimal training support
findings.description: The current process for voter verification is a manual process of a team of two people at Voatz. There is an identity verification provider in the process, but the voter is not able to vote until manual confirmation of their identity.

findings.title: Internal team has full access to voter PII
findings.description: Manual voter verification process requires access to verify identity. The small team that conducts the manual voter validation has full access to the federal or state issued identification images that are uploaded by the voters.
